frameDefinitions: An Experiencer feels an emotion as evoked as an Other.
A Cognizer makes a judgment about an Evaluee.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
A Defendant is tried by a Jury or Judge in a Court for Charges.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
The words in this frame refer to facial Expressions and the Possessors of those Expressions.
frameExamples: One might <t>pity</t> the frail old man in East Berlin.
JUDGMENT:  She <t>admired</t> Einstein for his character.
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
The state will <t>try</t> him for fraud.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Other</fen> is the person that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The  <fen>Situation</fen> is the circumstances or topic about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> feels an emotion.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> feels for the <fen>Other</fen>.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the judgment. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
Evaluee is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
The <fen>Judge</fen> heads the <fen>Court</fen> where the case is tried.  An expression referring to the <fen>Court</fen> may also stand in for the <fen>Judge</fen>.
The <fen>Defendant</fen> is being tried for the <fen>Charges</fen> in <fen>Court</fen>.

This role identifies the people who are charged by the <fen>Court</fen> to listen to the testimony, evidence, and arguments, and come to a consensus about the guilt or innocence of the <fen>Defendant</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Charges</fen> brought against the <fen>Defendant</fen>.
The <fen>Defendant</fen> is tried under the laws of the <fen>Governing_authority</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the case is tried.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the case is tried.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
This is the <fen>Expression</fen> made.
This is the person who exhibitis the <fen>Expression</fen>.
The emotion that is conveyed by a particular <fen>Expression</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
The boss appreciates <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
She viewed him with an appreciative <fex>gaze</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
<fex>Judge Murphy</fex> will try the defendant for murder.
<fex>The United States</fex> will try the accused bomber in a federal courthouse.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
